content: The Act is titled the "San Juan County Settlement Implementation Act" and involves the exchange of coal preference right lease applications. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of "bidding right" and "Secretary" in relation to coal lease sales under the Mineral Leasing Act. It explains how a bidding right can be used in place of monetary payments or as a credit against rental or royalty payments. The curr_chunk explains that a bidding right can be used instead of monetary payments for coal lease sales under the Mineral Leasing Act. The Secretary calculates payments owed to states based on the combined value of bidding rights and amounts received. The Secretary makes payments to states based on bidding rights used in coal lease sales, treated as payments under the Mineral Leasing Act. Bidding rights are fully transferable to any person. The bidding right issued under the Mineral Leasing Act terminates after 7 years, with tolling possible under certain circumstances. Transfer of bidding rights requires notification to the Secretary. The Secretary must complete the bidding rights valuation process for existing coal preference right lease settlements within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. CERTAIN LAND SELECTIONS OF THE NAVAJO NATION. The Navajo Nation's land selections under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974 are cancelled, and they are authorized to make new selections not exceeding 15,000 acres to replace the cancelled lands. Certain lands are excluded from selection. The Navajo Nation's land selections under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974 are cancelled, and they are authorized to make new selections not exceeding 15,000 acres to replace the cancelled lands. Land selection criteria include National Landscape Conservation System units, specific recreation and research areas, special management areas, and lands subject to leases or contracts under certain acts. The Navajo Nation is authorized to make new land selections not exceeding 15,000 acres to replace cancelled lands under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974. The selected land will be withdrawn from disposal, leasing, and development until placed into trust for the Navajo Nation. The value of the selected land is not limited by acreage restrictions. The Navajo Nation can select up to 15,000 acres of land to replace cancelled lands under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974. The value of the selected land must be equal to the cancelled land, determined by appraisals following specific standards. The Navajo Nation must complete appraisals for land selections within 18 months of the enactment of the Act. The boundary of the Navajo Reservation is defined by a map dated November 16, 2015.
